DataElement.preferredName: Radiation Surgery Planning Target Volume Surgical Margin Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the value, in mm, of the expansion margin, edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery, of the planning target volume, determined by precise outlining of an anatomic region for the purpose of delivering a high dose of radiotherapy to that concentrated area, and at the same time, minimizing the exposure and potential side effects of the adjacent tissues.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Radiation Surgery Planning Target Volume Surgical Margin
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the expansion margin, edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery, of the planning target volume, determined by precise outlining of an anatomic region for the purpose of delivering a high dose of radiotherapy to that concentrated area, and at the same time, minimizing the exposure and potential side effects of the adjacent tissues.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A radiation therapy technique that delivers radiation directly to the tumor while sparing the healthy tissue. Also called radiation surgery and stereotactic external beam irradiation.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure to treat cancer cells that use high energy beams.

Property.preferredDefinition: The precise outlining of an anatomic region for the purpose of delivering a high dose of radiotherapy to that concentrated area, and at the same time, minimizing the exposure and potential side effects of the adjacent tissues.:The edge or border of the tissue removed in cancer surgery.  The margin is described as negative or clean when the pathologist finds no cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has been removed.  The margin is described as positive or involved when the pathologist finds cancer cells at the edge of the tissue, suggesting that all of the cancer has not been removed.

Concepts.definition: A geometrical concept defined to select appropriate beam arrangements, taking into consideration the net effect of all possible geometrical variations, in order to ensure that the prescribed dose is actually absorbed in the clinical target volume.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements, including linear dimensions, volume, and weight, of a patient's tumor.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the value, in mm, of the surgical margin.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements, including linear dimensions, volume, and weight, of a patient's tumor.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.
